Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the situation by stating that a Popeyes manager was arrested for allegedly dipping chicken in cocaine-based flour to increase business sales. This is not supported by any evidence and is later revealed to be a fake news story.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence or credible source provided to back up the allegation made against the Popeyes manager.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the image and headline shared on Facebook are true and accurate without verifying the information. This assumption leads to the spread of false news and misinformation.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that the image and headline shared on Facebook are part of a prank or fake news story, as indicated by the website it originated from and the words "you've been pranked" cropped out of the image.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the image and headline shared on Facebook are fake and not based on any real events. This is confirmed by fact-checking efforts and the partnership between the source and Facebook to combat false news.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the claim.
